New episode out: "Leonardo da Vinci – On Art, Science, the Power of Wonder and the Birth of the Renaissance."

This conversation with Leonardo is a walk through the mind of someone who saw anatomy as art, designed flying machines while the rest of Europe was still figuring out bridges, and famously kept the Mona Lisa by his side for years (yes, perfectionism predates 'feature creep'). His curiosity crossed boundaries: he dissected bodies, planned ideal cities, engineered stage effects, and grappled with the tension between faith and reason—all while sporting pink tunics and sketching left-handed in mirror script. But what surprised me most was the personal cost of a relentlessly wandering mind, and the quiet acceptance that unfinished work might be a badge of genuine exploration.

If seeing the Renaissance—and our own limitations—through the eyes of its most curious son sounds intriguing, take a listen. I found his doubts as fascinating as his diagrams.

If you like the idea of peeking into the notebook of history's original multitasker, this one's for you.
